Problem:
Consider a complex-valued function defined as \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\), representing a time-dependent signal in the complex plane where \\( \omega \\) is a constant. This scenario analyzes the impact of the Fourier Transform \\( \hat{z}(\omega) \\), applied to this function and its influence over frequency domain representation.

If an intervention involves modifying \\( z(t) \\) by multiplying with another exponential signal \\( e^{i\sigma t} \\) at time T, will the Fourier Transform \\( \hat{z}(\omega) \\) only show a frequency shift by \\( \sigma \\)?
Explanation: Multiplying \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) by another exponential signal shifts its frequency by \\( \sigma \\). The Fourier Transform of the modified signal, therefore, becomes centered at \\( \omega + \sigma \\), indicating a direct frequency shift, without affecting other frequency components.
